comments.commentBody:
How do you know how many people are being denied coverage by insurance companies? I don't think they make those figures public.
Without an individual mandate there will not be as large a pool of insured, so costs will be higher. What makes you think people could afford those costs without being in a group? Did you ever price individual insurance policies? They are very expensive, and unaffordable for many people.
I have pre-existing, do you have a company in mind?

In theory, you are correct.  The problem arises when it comes time to pay the premiums for the insurance.  That's why the bill was named the Affordable Care Act, emphasis on affordable.  In theory, there is nothing stopping me from buying Mr. Romney's cool pad in La Jolla, except when it comes time to pay for it.

Mr. Krugman's statement that striking down the law will deny 30 million people health care insurance is intellectually dishonest. People will not be "denied" health care. They still have the option to purchase it, just as they would have to under the individual mandate. So, you might be a 26 yr old adults will come  off their parents' health insurance. This still does not "deny" them healthcare. They can still purchase it. Coming off his/her parents' health care doesn't prevent an adult from getting it. The other arugment might be then people will be denied health care based on previous conditions. This doesn't always happen. Some people may be denied health care coverage by some private insurers depending on the nature of the previous condition, some people are still approved for coverage despite a  previous condition.Calculating how many people will be denied by each and every private insurer because of these previous conditions might be difficult, but that number does not approach 30 million. Nevertheless, Mr. Krugman's claim that 30 million people will be denied insurance is a dishonest statement.

If the federal government's "frighteningly powerful means to control its citizens" (as DGA put it in another comment) result in my getting decent health insurance, along with millions of others, then I say good for the government. I have grave reservations about government intrusion into private affairs, but not in the area of facilitating medical care.

What astonishes me is that the core issue here--relieving human suffering--is not much mentioned in the press. My wife and I, for instance, pay $12,000 a year for health insurance. This is between a quarter and a third of our income--we both work full time, but we've suffered in the downturn, and because we're both about 60 there's no point in looking for a regular job--nobody even considers us when we apply. I need physical therapy for a hip issue of long standing, and I can't get it because my insurance doesn't cover physical therapy. So I hurt every day.

I manage reasonably well--many are far worse off than I am, and in much more desperate need of good medical care. Where are the voices of the Left, savaging those on the Right who place a higher priority on keeping taxes low for the rich than on relieving the physical and emotional suffering of many millions of their fellow citizens? As my Republican mother used to say as she watched the disaster in New Orleans unfold--I can't believe this is happening in America.

Broccoli is very very inexpensive compared to health insurance so the economy of scale argument is silly. I am low income and make a  conscious decision to buy organic broccoli so I can eat it regularly. But I can't afford health insurance anymore. We are talking about maybe $20/month for organic broccoli v. $900/month for health insurance, which is the price I've been quoted by the few health insurance companies that would even offer me insurance.

Recently a family member suffered a minor injury--a splinter driven deeply into her thumb--on a Friday evening. She was unsuccessful in removing it on her own and, in considerable pain, went to the emergency room. She would have gone to an urgent care center, but they were all closed for the evening. The doctor who treated her at the hospital told her she had done the right thing to come to the emergency room as she would definitely not have been able to remove the splnter herself. A few weeks after this incident she got the notice of benefits paid from her insurance company. For removing the splinter, the charge was $1000, although the amount actually paid was somewhat less.

So, two questions: Do you consider that a catastrophic event? If not, how many people--young adults or otherwise--do you think would find having to pay a $1000 bill to be a financial burden? And, what would happen if a second event costing $1000 or a bit more happened not too much later? For some people $100 could be hard to come up with, let alone $1000.

When people live unhealthy lifestyles, they increase the burden of costs on the healthcare system, especially as they get older. And to some extent, we all bear the burden of these expenses, especially for the elderly. The whole point of expanding the number of people buying insurance is to get healthier people to buy insurance. So the government clearly has an interest in people living a healthy lifestyle. So why can't the government mandate the purchase of broccoli, especially since the more people buy broccoli the more economies of scale will drive down the price and make it cheaper for the poor.

Among the many questions that the Solicitor General could not seem to answer were: Can the federal government mandate commerce in order to regulate it? Why should people pay for a type of insurance that they will not need or are unlikely to need? How do you differentiate between commerce and non-commerce? Can a contract be coerced? Why should a young adult pay for anything other than catastrophic health insurance? The SG seems to believe that a product (cell phones) doesn't have a market, but a that a concept (health care) does. Questions can never be wrong; only answers can be. If the Solicitor General could not provide cogent answers, don't blame the people asking the questions. His failure to answer effectively is only evidence that the questions needed to be asked.

We won't be surprised when, appended to the courts decision to kill the health care Act the following:

"Our consideration is limited to the present circumstances, for the problem of [health care] generally presents many complexities."

- just to borrow an admission of judicial bad faith and otherwise impeachable behavior from Bush v. Gore.

They will never admit the real reason for their decision: that it's legislation credited to the Obama administration.

They will never admit the real purpose of their decision: Just part of the right wing's concerted effort to not only deny Obama a second term, but to erase any evidence that he had a first term.

I guess, Justice Thomas, your feelings about high tech lynchings depends only on which side of the rope you're on.
Obviously you have not yet had to pay more than $100,000 for a heart bypass or more than a million for a heart or liver transplant.

What part of Dr. Krugman's statistic did you not understand? Only 5-10% of private pay medical costs are ever actually paid/collected? And you actually believe you're subsidizing my healthcare? Really? Really?

Keep living in La-La Land, Hugh. Must be nice to have enough money to be able to pay the outrageous cost of healthcare today while insulating yourself from the other 99% of us.

Do you know who Kent Snyder was? He was Ron Paul's 2008 campaign manger, he was uninsured, and he died leaving a $400,000 debt for medical care. A fund-raising effort on to help pay off the debt raised less than $35,000.

Do you have the wherewithal to handle a bill of $400,000 or would either your survival or your death after accumulating charges of that magnitude mean that other people would be left holding the bag? If you are wealthy enough to not worry about $400,000 or even multi-million dollar medical bills, then good for you. But it would be much more seemly if you didn't spout off as if most people who are uninsured are in the same category. And if you aren't that wealthy, then you are being as irreponsible as anyone else who chooses to go without insurance.

The premise that all of the uninsured are deadbeats is nonsense. Many of us pay our medical expenses out of our own pockets.

And we pay far more for a given treatment than do the insured. The simple truth is that the responsibly uninsured (not an oxymoron) help subsidize lower rates for the insured.

No, no; that's all right. No need to thank me.

As for whether the new Medicaid expansion is coercive, if a state opts to drop out of the program, does the federal government stop collecting taxes that fund Medicaid from the state's residents ?

The hubris began with forced busing and Roe v. Wade, and it continues today.  The crusading judicial activism of the liberal 60s and 70s has given way to the crusading judicial activism of the conservative era.  I think the problem stems from nominating only graduates of leading law schools who have little experience outside of the law.  We need a little more perspective and humility on the bench.  Is this a right wing problem?  I see nothing to make me believe that we wouldn't see the same from the left if Scalia dropped dead tomorrow and was replaced by a liberal.

Cruelty -- in the forms of selfish greed, callous indifference to the poor and others, gifting the wealthy at the expense of the poor -- unites and binds the modern-day, morally corrupt Republican Party.

ACA is a much better law than existing one. Many provisions, including preventive medicine and electronic health record requirement, are essential to modern medicine. It's not perfect by all means, but is is a strong step in the right direction!

The issues discussed, the give and take in the SCOTUS, the arguments pro and con for two years, all originate in this patchwork quilt of a law, which thankfully is now at least accepted as politically correct to describe as Obamacare.

The intent to offer a viable national health program was always commendable and necessary. Had it been constructed by a congress devoid of vested interests insisting on so many varied proposals which were piled into the the bill without sufficient debate and little compromise to accommodate the greater good for all the people, we could have been satisfied. Rather, had the politicians denied the lobbyists and the self interest of the politicians in allowing the lobbyists who wrote portions, at least, of the bill, all may have been fine by now. We the people were once again given short shrift and disregarded by the very people we elected to Congress to represent us the people, not the lobbyists.

So the patchwork quilt did not cover the essentials needed and now we have an impasse, and once again the incompetence of the politicians results in the Supreme Court coming to the rescue. And they are unlikely to satisfy every interest. Congress is responsible, for if they had done the job they were elected to do, the Supreme Court would never have been needed to do what should have been done on Capital Hill. We the people deserve better and are not going to get it from a Congress who hold the people in contempt as they cater to the lobbyists.

Your interpretation of the constitution would give congress essentially unfettered powers to dictate and control commerce in all of its forms.  The supreme court drew limits on the power of the commerce clause long before any of the current justices were present. Congress can regulate commerce -- it cannot mandate it.

When a person without the ability to pay for medical care is ill and walks into a hospital the physicians are required to treat her. The cost of that medical treatment is borne by other patients who can pay either through direct payment or medical insurance.

The specious "The government could make them buy broccoli," argument is flawed. The analogous situation is a hungry person without the ability to pay for food walking into a grocery store and demanding food. Unlike the hospital, a store owner is not required to provide service and goods to those who cannot pay. The owner may feed her if he chooses, but he's going to have to continually raise prices for all customers if he's going to stay in business. But he also has the choice of sending her away hungry.

The Affordable Health Care Act is an attempt to see that people who can afford to pay to shop in the store can continue to do so. Those who can't afford groceries will get help paying for them. But if everyone pays for their groceries the store stays in business and everyone will get fed.

The US Constitution places limits on the Federal govt. The Constitution does not place the same limits on the States. The other 49 States could pass Romneycare anytime they want without any legal challenges.
The question is: why don't more States enact the individual mandate, especially 'blue' States?

Sigh. Read the Constitution.

"The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the States, are reserved to the States respectively..."

There's nothing in the Constitution that prohibits States from doing what Massachusetts has done. What is prohibited, is the Federal government taking powers which properly belong to the individual States.

Why are liberals against State-by-State Obama-Romneycare, for those States where the people want it? Because they want to cram it down the throats of States where most people DON'T want it. You see, it is about liberty.
PJF, are you serious? Conservatives are against Romney care. Romneys been getting hammered on this since day one of the campaign.  Have you watched a single debate?

I've never seen conservatives explain this: They say the Obamacare individual mandate to buy health insurance infringes on the liberty of individuals. But Romneycare does the same, only the coercion comes from the state government instead of the federal government. But Its the same from the affected individual's point of view.

So why aren't conservatives against Romneycare if they really are motivated by concerns about liberty? Answer: Its not really about liberty. Its about politics.

Don't underestimate the Supremes' ability to ignore what they did 10 minutes ago. They're just another arm of the Republican party. See Bush v. Gore, where they asserted Bush's right to be POTUS despite having lost the election, because there was the potential for a constitutional conflict.
I wouldn't count on it. It may be the opposite. Justices would rather swallow the ACA to open the door for SS privatization. That is more realistic. Otherwise they are nothing but paid hacks!

"By the way, another pet conservative project — private accounts to replace Social Security — relies on, yes, mandatory contributions from individuals."

Seems that the prospect of privatizing Social Security by forcing citizens to purchase retirement savings plans would become untenable if the individual mandate to purchase health insurance is declared unconstitutional.

Maybe this is a silver lining in a Supreme Court decision to scuttle the ACA. Such a decision also implies that the only way to accomplish universal health care (which will eventually become economically unavoidable) is by a single payer system.

I've been working at an answer for the day my daughter asks this question, if ever. If not, I will not bring it up because I agree with commenters that children have NO preconceived notion of what is a normal family.

I chose to cut my father out of my life because: 1) he does not love us and have made no attempts to be a father my entire life, and 2) blood does not dictate the bonds of love.

If my daughter ever asks, I hope I will give an answer that holds no judgment for the character of my father; that it will be matter-of-fact with no unnecessary emotive vocabulary as I've made peace with this fact of my life; and that ultimately it is about teaching my daughter that when you profess to love someone, it is your responsibility to love well.

My father has no desire for a family, has no desire to love us, and thus he has no place in my family. Simple.

John, I realize it's past my curfew, however, did you somehow miss the comment I made in reply to your paeon to Chaos @ 10:40 a.m. where I praised you to the highest...nice payback, John, coming to the defense of a total stranger from your hometown who really put the knock on the puzzles young constructor!

Howie never Hyde from the truth
Howie, everybody should feel free to their opinion as to the puzzle without being attacked for it by fellow bloggers here.   That's one of the nice aspects of this blog.

John, Check out your fellow Chicagoian's comment at the time in my comment...then perhaps you'll get it...and as for last night's comment with RIA, he and I have made our peace!

Howie

This is one of those days when I have given up hope in humanity's "last best hope." Like many other Americans, I have placed little credenceor confidence in the SCOTUS at least since Bush v. Gore,   It has become, on its face and to its core, a strictly partisan political institution, and in the case of the Thomases and Scalia an "in-your-face" partisan political institution.  If I had no children, I wouldn't really care; I am 60 and likely will be dead in no more than another 20-30 years.  But my children and their children will be here, and when I permit me to dwell on the state or nation is in, I just feel lost.  Politicans lie and continue to lie even after they are called out on their lying.  Big Money always wins, even when ordinary people die from the thoughtless callousness underlaying Big Money.  Whites are still fearing blacks, blacks are still hating whites, hispanics, asians, arabs and others ahve been added to this steamy, hateful mix.  And on this health care reform we have a court that engages in the basest sophistry as a prelude to striking down reform.  No wonder so many Americans are on antidepressants.

I am independent write-in candidate for president. I have posted at least 150 comments but I'm not verified. It's the price I pay as candidate for president. Sense over ship.

I have the best Health Care Plan. We access ourselves two loose pennies out of pocket for every fast food, Walmart Target, supermarket purchase and reward this voluntary gratuity to the bottom end help.

Two voluntary pennies for every item purchased puts a dollar for every hour worked into Medical Assurance Accounts that will cover more than 25 million people.

Out of that weekly Medical Assurance Account $5 goes to Catastrophic Illness Pool. 12 million X 5 X in 6 weeks = $360 million dollars for transplants, heart attacks, baby births, broken legs and preexisting conditions. Outsiders shall be invited to join the pool.

Expect a giant migration from insurance co.'s to my Health cooperative commonly funded by our loose pennies. Given the space I can explain how this program benefits the whole nation with every single person in USA covered at half the projected cost of Obama Care.

Today's essay is the Supreme Coats. I'm 20 days away from submitting my cases that according to an Act of Congress must be heard by the Supreme Coats at the top of their docket.

I have a constitutional right to deliver a nationwide speech on PBS. Besides challenging ABC, NBC, CBS, FOX, and PBS licenses, I'm representing the speech rights of all American people.

http://youtu.be/Jgmfcd_zY_Y

http://michaelslevinson.com

It is very hard to understand why Scalia and Thomas make a pretense of listening to cases and making judgements.

They are not justices. They are right-wing bobble heads. Any five-year-old child could predict their rulings on every case based on its politics and who benefits.

At least Thomas does not even feign engagement. Scalia is so undignified, smug, and gratuitously sadistic he soils the high seat he occupies.

The priceless part is the fact that every proven life saving treatment , whether it is chemotherapy or a new cardiac transplant drug, was proven to be better than its predecessor by having courageous patients voluntarily participate in clinical research studies with no guarantee that the treatments they would receive might actually have a worse outcome than standard treatment.
This fact is embedded in every treatment millions of patients receive every year, and is not only a factor in today's treatments, but also in the long chain of research proven treatments that preceded them.
Whatever one might do to ration care or focus resources on patients who have more years of life to gain, this principle of working together, sharing one's own life for the sake of discovering a better treatment for future patients, will still apply, and it is indeed priceless, and it is indeed collective. In each Kaplan Mayer survival curve, each point on every line -- as the lines descend, ultimately, to depict the collective survival of one group of treated patients versus another --  is made by a person's death--and such collective knowledge is impossible in the every-man for-himself, winner-take-all, rich-people-only, let-them-eat-broccoli world of Scalia and his ilk. To the contrary, as resources become constrained, it is even more essential that such research clarify how precious health dollars should be spent. 
There are not enough dying millionaires to test all these drugs on them alone.

Hear, hear, Doctor. As a person of science, you have articulated brilliantly the outrage so many of us are feeling about this bloated bloviator who, as a Supreme should by definition be a superb speaker, but in his self-aggrandizing arrogance, cannot even articulate a cogent argument for sentencing millions of his countrymen to painful, withering, needless deaths.

But in keeping with Prof. Krugman's theme of "faith," I would suggest that, rather than leave Scalia alone to eat his boiled broccoli, let the man show his good faith to the rest of us by renouncing his taxpayer-funded health insurance. Why should we have to foot the bill for his care? If he wants insurance, let him go buy it, paid for out of his own pocket, with his own "hard-earned" dollars!

Now THAT would be an eloquent statement...

RC, in the Heartland: There are so many brilliant comments to Professor Krugman's column today, but I must say yours is not only brilliant, but should be held up as the epitome of all that is supposed to be sacred in our country. You happen to see and voice that we are all truly interconnected and each have a part to play in our society's health care problems. Unlike Scalia [I cannot honor him with the title of Justice because he is so undeserving] who has the 'lifetime power' to sit in judgement of our laws and the effect they have on us all mutually but who has stated he can't even be bothered with reading this law. How is he then supposed 'judge it aside from comparing it to broccoli?.

Thank you, RC, for your honest evaluation as seen by a first-hand view. It irks me no end that Cheney, who has had no heart when it came to the very people he was supposed to care about while in office for all those years, managed to receive this donor heart when I know of many other people so much more deserving, but lacking the funds which purchased the power it takes to determine who wins in these life and death situations. I believe that without the power of his name/position, he would still be on the wait list for that heart which would be the appropriate place for him to eat all his broccoli.

The new heart beating in Cheney's chest cost far more than the $200,000 of his hospital bill, and the $500,000 spent for the past 20 months with an artificial heart pumping his blood. The real cost, which we have all invested in over decades of research, practice innovation, and hard-earned gains from other patients with the courage to take the risk of being the first to try yet unproven treatments -- all of this is truly as priceless as life itself. And it is in this way, most of all, and to a far deeper and more intimate degree than merely sharing in an insurance risk pool, that our fates and collective health are inextricably bound. Sharing the simple financial risk ought to have been the easiest, most trivial part of this covenant. Yet, on the basis of financial risk sharing alone, Scalia has trivialized ALL OF HEALTH CARE , as if it were a matter of eating broccoli or not, all while mocking a law that he boasts he has not even read, even as he threatens to single handedly kill it, and millions of people as he does so.
As a physician who has cared for hundreds of patients exactly like Cheney, I am outraged by the contempt that the Supreme Court has over human life and the sacred sacrifices that millions have made, in their living and dying, to advance the science and art of medicine.
If Scalia will not pay for his share of the financial risk, nor should he partake of any of the innovations made possible only by our collective efforts.
Let him eat broccoli -- alone.

That's great, except that studies demonstrate that when the uninsured become insured, they use the ER at the same rate as before. Hence, the ACA will not change this at all.

Don't blame it on the ER - the real villian is the medical elite - starting with physicians (and in this, I am referring not to primary care docs and pediatricians, but to most specialists).

Specialist physicians earn on average $450K per year. Add about $100K to that for those in big cities.

Is this type of salary really needed to attract "the best and brightest?" (remember how bright Wall Street CEO's are).

Pharma nets about $300B/year in US profits.

What do we get for all this?

Mostly garbage medical care - very well-trained, intelligent, but over-payed (and therefore, out of touch) physicians dispensing garbage medications (the vast majority with almost no curative value and many with very serious adverse effects that occur in large numbers of patients).

That's why I'm opposed to ACA - our country is better off with less people in this system.

Over 40% of our population already pays out of pocket to get holistic medical care. Imagine what the number would be if this type of care were part of the insurance scheme?

The ACA and the medical-industrial complex are designed to force people into the "sick-care-management" system.

Actually, Chris, here in Australia, with universal health care, the emergency rooms of hospitals are used for what they were intended for -- medical emergencies -- and not for primary care, which is taken care of in clinics and doctors' offices (called surgeries here).  I suspect that once folk get used to the idea that they can, in fact, get care elsewhere, that will be the case in the US as well.

Cite your studies, Chris, because I don't believe you. Why would anybody with insurance go to the emergency room if they did not absolutely have to?
People with less urgent medical problems will have to wait hours and hours to be seen by a doctor in the ER, because the ER must handle the most critical cases first.

One of the big problems here is the myth that Americans get healthcare just fine if they go to the ER. That's what the Scalia's are thinking, or half thinking in their cloud of rosy denial.

Don't worry, everybody is getting what they need by heading out to the local emergency ward--they just have to suffer a little inconvenience. This is what powers the right wing argument that healthcare reform adds no real value.

The irony is that those who rely on the ER to salvage their consicences don't follow that reliance far enough to compute the cost. We as taxpayers pay through the nose to finance the ER's delivering service to the destitute.

We pay orders of magnitude more to deliver medical services via that route instead of through proper channels, and the service received is far inferior for those who are seeking non-emergency medical care via the ER because they have nowhere else to go--the reason being that ER's are structured to deliver emergency medical service only, not routine medical service. They don't know how and don't have the equipment, procedures, or other resources necessary to do that.

But that's a matter of taking the time and having the conscience to understand what's really going on, isn't it? Scalia, the other Republican Supreme Court appointees, and the rightwingers who are hardly distinguishable from sharks smelling blood in the water, can't be bothered with that.

So much for "family values."

In Bush v. Gore the Supreme Court abandoned, once and forever, the myth of the rule of law -- the concept that judges neutrally attempt to apply legal principles instead of just conjuring up arguments to support predetermined outcomes based on personal bias or vested interests. The justices in the majority revealed themselves as simply political hacks in black robes who (unlike other political hacks) are unelected and blessed with lifetime appointments. In Bush a majority composed of self-described limited government federalist defenders of states' rights usurped Florida's uncontested authority to conduct statewide elections to select national officeholders. Why? Because the outcome they wanted dictated such usurpation. And in a final gesture of arrogance, they ruled that their decision in Bush should never be cited as precedent in a future case -- an explicit admission of its indefensibility.

So exactly why is anybody surprised to see this shameless opportunism repeated?

I can't imagine the additional courses costing the college $180 per credit hour to teach. After all, the facilities (classrooms, restrooms, etc.) including janitorial services are already paid for. It's simply that state budget cuts have hit California schools, including Junior colleges, hard. Since teachers are the biggest expense they have been cut the most.

I was a board member of a K-12 Los Angeles area school district which has an arrangement with a non-profit, like that proposed for Santa Monica College. The school district contracts with a non-profit to administer the program including collecting the fees and paying the teachers (which are usually happy to get the extra work). But the individual operating the non-profit pocketed several hundred thousand dollars a year as his compensation.

This just didn't seem fair to me while the kids whose parents couldn't afford the classes were shortchanged. It's not the way our public education system is supposed to work.

All Americans must buy food. The government subsidizes and gives food away to some groups of old and poor people. Some people need more food than others. Some go bankrupt feeding their families (along with their other expenses). Some people are irresponsible in their food use. Some people spend all of their money on other things, then expect charity from private or public institutions to feed them (food bank users, aka free riders). Congress could greatly improve this inefficient marketplace for food by mandating a standard grocery list for all Americans, ensuring that all are fed equally, and all receive their nutrients through insisting on the inclusion of, say, BROCCOLI.

I do not want congress to have the power to dictate my grocery bill, or my healthcare, in part because I fear all of the many other things that could be mandated if such a precedent was allowed. And I find your ignorance of the logic of constitutional law frightening. You appear delusional.

I would rather have Medicare for all, but the right-wingers scream about taxes all the time because they don't want to tax their wealthy campaign contributors. Look at how we could not even get rid of the Bush tax cuts for the wealthy. The  political system is totally corrupted by big campaign and lobby money. And the insurance companies have a very big lobby.

Car insurance rules are made by the States, not the federal govt. Michigan could adopt an individual mandate anytime without any legal challenges at all. Why hasn't Michigan adopted an individual mandate like MA?

I am about to pay my federal income taxes, and a portion of my tax dollars goes to provide Justice Scalia's gold plated health insurance coverage, as well as Dick Cheney's 25 years of cardiac care culminating in the replacement of his 71 year old heart. I wish that I could choose not to make that mandated payment.

I am mandated by the state to pay for insurance for my car because of the damage I might do to others or myself while operating that car. It's true that I can avoid that mandate by choosing not to own a car, but no one can choose not to become ill or injured. Everyone who is alive will eventually impose a financial liability on the rest of us by incurring medical expenses while being uninsured. Therefore, requiring health insurance coverage is no different than requiring auto coverage.

Rapidly escalating health care costs are a burden on our national economy and as such easily come within the authority of the federal government to regulate under the Commerce clause of the Constitution. If the government can require me to pay a tax to fund Medicare, it can require me to make a contribution towards my medical care by buying insurance.

Don't worry, we won't.

But the notion that everyone without insurance now or the recent past has none voluntarily is nonsense as well.

Many cannot get insurance due to pre-existing conditions pay high rates for the care they receive, and quite involuntarily. Similarly, people who can buy insurance but cannot do so as a member of a group pay very high rates, subsidizing everyone else.

This why your voluntary decision to pay more merits little thanks - it was your choice. most in your shoes had no such choice.

My wife and I operate a small company and pay about $28,000 per year for our individual health insurance.  We both have pre-existing conditions and have been told we are “uninsurable” outside of our company’s group plan.  Essentially the insurance industry is “forcing” us to keep working at this business until we can both qualify for Medicare (assuming the Supreme Court doesn’t determine that to be unconstitutional).  Of course we always have the option to give up health insurance and go bankrupt.  There was a time that this market manipulation by the insurance industry would be considered racketeering.  Now, with psychotic Republicans in Congress and the Supreme Court, it is simply regarded as good business.
